DataElement.preferredName: Therapy Complementary and Alternative Medicine Administered Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator that asks whether nontraditional therapeutic agents/procedures were administered for treatment to alter a disease process (e.g., herbal preparation, vitamin, massage, magnets).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Therapy Complementary and Alternative Medicine Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the action of non-traditional therapeutic agents or procedures added to or substituted for treatment to alter a disease process (e.g., herbal preparations, vitamins, massage, magnets).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Property.preferredDefinition: Practices not generally recognized by the medical community as standard or conventional medical approaches and used to replace, enhance or complement standard treatments. Complementary medicine includes dietary supplements, megadose vitamins, herbal preparations, special teas, acupuncture, massage therapy, magnet therapy, spiritual healing, and meditation.:Given.

Concepts.definition: A group of diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not presently considered to be part of conventional medicine. Complementary medicine as being used together with conventional medicine, whereas alternative medicine is used in place of conventional medicine. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) groups CAM practices into four domains, recognizing there can be some overlap: mind-body medicine; biologically based practices, manipulative and body-based practices, and energy medicine. In addition, NCCAM studies CAM whole medical systems, which cut across all domains.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: updated for ISO compliance for use on new protocol

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2022.12.28 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001837. aj

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

RepresentationTerm.changeDescription: 10.3.20 TL changed WFS from RETIRED PHASED OUT to RETIRED ARCHIVED. Changed Workflow Status DBW 04-27-2016

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Prior use of herbal products that may decrease PSA levels

ReferenceDocuments.name: PBTC_Text1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has patient received any of the following herbal medications and fruits within 7 days prior to enrollment: Herbal medications include, but are not limited to St. John's wort, Kava, ephedra (ma huang), gingko biloba, dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), yohimbe, saw palmetto, and ginseng?  Fruits include the CYP3A inhibitors Seville oranges, grapefruit, pummelos, or exotic citrus fruits.

ReferenceDocuments.name: PBTC_Text2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has patient received any of the following herbal medications or fruits within 7 days prior to enrollment: Herbal medications include, but are not limited to St. John's wort, Kava, ephedra (ma huang), gingko biloba, dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), yohimbe, saw palmetto, and ginseng? Fruits include the CYP3A4/5 inhibitors Seville oranges, grapefruit, pummelos, or exotic citrus fruits?

ReferenceDocuments.name: PBTC_Text3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has patient been off herbal preparations or medications for at least 1 week prior to enrollment (3 weeks for St. John's wort)? These herbal medications include, but are not limited to: cannabis products, St. John's wort, kava, ephedra (ma huang), gingko biloba, dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), yohimbe, saw palmetto, and ginseng.

ReferenceDocuments.name: PBTC_Text4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has the patient received St Johns wort within the last 21 days?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient agree to discontinue use of any complementary or alternative medicines, including natural herbal products or folk remedies?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Prior medications or herbal products including grapefruits, grapefruit hybrids, pomelos, star fruits, Seville oranges, pomegranates, or the juice from any of these?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient use herbal medications/preparations (except for vitamins), alternative/complimentary medications, immunosuppressive therapy, or other prohibited medications
